Hi <@UAJH2818E>, thank you for your critical thoughts/feedback.

In general, the "vision" was to implement a quantum network simulator that could send wave function inputs to various optical devices (i.e., beam splitters, phase shifters, etc.) assembled in an arbitrary configuration and be able to calculate the resulting wave functions at any point in the optical system. With the right configuration, this simulator should be able to model seminal experiments like the Hong-Ou-Mandel effect, the Mach-Zehnder interferometer, etc.

The idea being, that the simulation is "relatively" quantum mechanically accurate since it's based on quantum physics first principles and given this mathematical accuracy, there would likely be quantum operations involved in the simulations that would benefit from a speed-up provided by a "surrogate modeling" solution potentially through ML techniques.

I believe my problem has been I've only been looking at closed quantum systems which generally do not involve non-linearities. Hence my comment "since quantum state transformations are performed using unitary operators, linear algebra, it's very unlikely that any ML solution will be faster". And probably to your earlier point of 'dissipative systems'.

So I've started looking at how I might create a simple model of one of the quantum optics experiments previously mentioned which includes coupling with the environment to investigate further.

> I believe my problem has been I've only been looking at closed quantum systems which generally do not involve non-linearities.
That is kinda-wrong. Non-linearities do not arise because of closeness/openess of a system, but rather from some components (like X3 nonlinear mediums, X4...) in the optical path.
Openess simply complicates everything by making it so you have losses and therefore mixed states, but if you just have an optical setup such as one you describe you tipically don't need to care about losses. The beams are usually well focused.

text:
The key point is, however, what and where you want to simulate.
If you are in the deep quantum regime, with few photons per mode, a discrete description in the Fock space is easy and there are tools to address this. See NeuralQuantum in Julia (now abandoned) and NetKet (python). (I work on both projects).
